Award.AwardTitle: The absolute calibration of Cepheid and Mira Period-Luminosity relations in the near-infrared
Award.AbstractNarration: The investigators will analyze observational time-series near-infrared data of variable stars in order to reduce uncertainties in the Hubble constant, which is used to determine the age of the universe. They will focus on variable stars that belong to eclipsing binaries in nearby galaxies and us stellar atmosphere models, in order to calculate accurate stellar radii. The calculated stellar radii and measured periods and magnitudes will be used to derive distances that will be incorporated in the extragalactic "cosmic distance ladder," from which an improved value of the Hubble constant can be derived. This work will have broader impacts in that it involve the participation of a graduate student from an underrepresented group, and the PI will give bilingual talks to the public and maintain a public website in Spanish.

POR.DRECONTENT:
How old is the Universe, and what is it made of? What is its ultimate fate? In order to answer these questions with increasingly higher certainty, astronomers need to know the rate at which the space between galaxies is stretching. This rate is known as the "Hubble constant", named after the famous astronomer who first estimated its value. In order to measure H0 (as it's commonly abbreviated), we must determine precise and accurate distances to other galaxies. The best tool to do this is a family of stars known as Cepheid variables. One of the major aims of this project was to better understand the fundamental properties of these stars so they can serve as even better distance indicators. We studied these variables in a satellite galaxy of the Milky Way, known as the Large Magellanic Cloud, using a telescope partially funded by the NSF.

Cepheid variables are somewhat rare objects and can only be found in galaxies with young stars. Yet in many instances, astronomers may wish to measure the distance to a galaxy that only has older stars. For that reason, in this project we also studied another family of stars known as Mira variables. These are harder to study because they change in brightness more slowly (sometimes taking years to repeat a single cycle) and their variations are not as regular as those of Cepheids. In the past, the study of Mira variables required large numbers of observations but thanks to modern statistical techniques. we now have the ability to study them using smaller data sets (which are easier to collect). In partnership with colleagues in the Department of Statistics, we developed and tested techniques that enabled us to identify Mira variables in a relatively nearby galaxy known as M33, and establish the relation between the period of pulsation of these stars and the amount of light that they emit (their luminosity).

Beyond a better characterization of the so-called Period-Luminosity relations of Cepheids and Miras, this project resulted in the development of statistical techniques that can be used to study other data sets with sparse coverage and poor measurements. The astronomy graduate student working on this project became proficient in so-called "machine learning" techniques that can be applied to many large datasets from a variety of fields in industry and society in general.
